abstract.p: Steven Grimm letter on July 13 article about reversal of earth's magnetic field contends that signs of global warming on earth could be attributable to changes in magnetic field (S)

block.p: ''Will Compasses Point South?'' points out several consequences of a weakened magnetic field: damage to the ozone layer, especially in the polar regions; more solar radiation reaching Earth; and the disorientation of sea turtles and other animals that use magnetism to navigate.

Overfishing is probably behind recent declines in turtle populations, but can the collapsing magnetic field be the reason we see a diminished ozone layer with large holes over the poles, elevated skin cancer rates in Australia, and a rise in surface temperatures?

''Will Compasses Point South?'' points out several consequences of a weakened magnetic field: damage to the ozone layer, especially in the polar regions; more solar radiation reaching Earth; and the disorientation of sea turtles and other animals that use magnetism to navigate.

Overfishing is probably behind recent declines in turtle populations, but can the collapsing magnetic field be the reason we see a diminished ozone layer with large holes over the poles, elevated skin cancer rates in Australia, and a rise in surface temperatures?
The effects seem to fit the predictions, even if conventional wisdom points the finger solely at manmade pollution.
